title: 2019-11-07 - Swen (computer worm)
plain_text:
# Swen (computer worm)

**en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swen_(computer_worm)**

Contributors to Wikimedia projects

Swen

**Common name** Swen worm

**Technical name** Win32/Swen

Win32/Swen.worm.106496 (AhnLab)
W32/Swen.A@mm (Authentium Command)
[I-Worm/Swen.A (AVG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AVG_(software))
[Win32/Swen.A@mm (BitDefender)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BitDefender)
Win32/Swen.A.Worm (CA)
[Win32/Swen.A (ESET)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ESET)
[Email-Worm.Win32.Swen (Kaspersky)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kaspersky_Anti-Virus)
[W32/Swen@MM (McAfee)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McAfee)
W32/Swen.A@mm (Norman)
[W32/Gibe.C.worm (Panda)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panda_Security)
[W32/Gibe-F (Sophos)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sophos)
[Email-Worm.Win32.Swen (Sunbelt Software)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunbelt_Software)
[W32.Swen.A@mm (Symantec)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NortonLifeLock)
[WORM_SWEN.A (Trend Micro)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trend_Micro)
I-Worm.Swen.A1 (VirusBuster)

**Aliases**

**Type** [Computer worm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_worm)

**Subtype** [Mass mailer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_mailer)

**Point of isolation** September 18, 2003

**[Operating system(s) affected](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operating_system)** Windows 95 to Windows XP

**Filesize** [106-496 bytes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bytes)

**Swen is a** [mass mailing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_mailer) [computer worm written in](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_worm) [C++. It sends an email which contains the](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C%2B%2B)
[installer for the virus, disguised as a Microsoft Windows update, although it also works on](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_Windows)
[P2P](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peer-to-peer) [filesharing networks,](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filesharing) [IRC and newsgroups' websites. It was first analyzed on September](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IRC)
[18, 2003, however, it might have infected computers before then. It disables firewalls and](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Firewall_(computing))
[antivirus programs.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antivirus_programs)

## Infection

### Self-installation


-----

[The virus first sends itself via email with an attachment, posing as an update for Windows.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Email)
[The attachment can have a .com,](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COM_file) [.scr,](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/.scr) [.bat,](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/.bat) [.pif, or](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Program_information_file) [.exe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/.exe) [file extension. If its file name starts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File_extension)
with the letters P, Q, U, or I, It displays a fake Microsoft Update dialogue box, asking if the
user wants to install a Microsoft Security Update with the two choices "Yes" and "No". If the
user presses "Yes", it displays a fake progress bar while installing the fake update. When
finished, it displays another dialogue box saying: Microsoft Internet Update Pack This has
been successfully installed. The malware then re-executes itself, followed by yet another
dialogue box saying: Microsoft Security Update Pack This update does not need to be
installed on this system. If the user chooses "No", the malware will still install itself silently in
the background. Next, it checks for certain criteria by opening another dialogue box,
[prompting the user for their email address, username, password, SMTP and](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Email_address) [POP3 server](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/POP3)
addresses. After completing the said fields, the worm then makes a copy of itself in the
```
C:\Windows folder as <random characters>.exe . The virus finally moves all information

```
to the copy and terminates.

### Autostart

[The worm creates the following registry entry to execute upon startup:](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_Registry) `{{{1}}}`
